Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Adaptive Small-systems for data Analytic Pain Management (ERC-ASAP)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The National Academy of Medicine's Institute of Medicine (IOM) estimates that 116 million people in the United States are impacted by pain every year, at an annual cost to the country in the hundreds of billion dollars. Chronic pain conditions are particularly difficult to treat, since pain is a complex experience that is not the result of a single factor. The key to better understand the complexity of pain conditions is to identify the biological changes it creates. The Engineering Research Center for Adaptive Small-systems for data Analytic Pain management (ERC-ASAP) proposes to place miniaturized autonomous sensing systems in several areas of the body. This will allow simultaneous monitoring of biological activities across multiple organs, providing insight into the causes of chronic pain and its onset. This grant enables planning activities to establish the proposed Center, potentially leading to new breakthrough technologies for diagnosis and monitoring that could alter the national pain management landscape.

The activities of the NSF ERC-ASAP Planning Grant will allow for the development of the management structures and multi-disciplinary team formation. Planning grant activities will also include a diverse set of stakeholder community members, necessary for effective convergent engineering practices. The center goals are to engage representatives from the main stakeholder community for constructive dialogues to identify challenges and solutions. One major outcome will be to co-develop the center mission and goals with active, continuous user community collaboration and investment. Expert-guided stakeholder engagement workshops will build and establish a strong partnership with institutional and industrial collaborators, as well as medical experts, systems engineers and data scientists, health professionals, decision and social behavior scientists, and federal regulators. In addition, a state-wide online survey and questionnaire will be conducted within the health service community to identify specific challenges, delivery, treatment options, and payer models for a device-driven engineering approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to enable the creation of miniaturized systems capable of autonomous data collection and treatment delivery within the human body, utilizing convergent activities to bring together stakeholders from diverse, interdisciplinary backgrounds including research, industry, regulatory bodies, insurance providers, social scientists, and medical professionals. The main focus areas of the proposal are ingestible devices to interrogate gastrointestinal (GI) signals and enable therapies, creating a new class of integrated systems that sense biochemical and physical information to enable data-driven healthcare. Our convergent activities include participation in 1) the NSF-sponsored cohort meetings, 2) strategic planning sessions—learning by mentoring, and 3) an ERC stakeholder engagement workshop—building a community. It should be noted here that, in light of the news of discontinuation of the NSF ERC full proposal submission, the nature of the planning grant activities has been redirected from developing the survey for the pain management community to establishing proof-of-concept minimally invasive sensing and treatment microsystems as well as training programs aimed at introducing this technology and science to undergraduate researchers and early-stage scientists. Overall, the convergent research activities made possible by the support of the NSF ERC planning grant have built a solid foundation for the development of next-generation minimally invasive ingestible devices.

 

In the first year, as well as the second-year extension of the NSF ERC activities, stakeholders have built upon their accomplishments and significantly expanded on the foundational concepts outlined in the convergent activities. From this, collaborations were established between the School of Medicine at John’s Hopkins University (JHU), the University of Maryland, Baltimore (UMB), Morgan State University, Northeastern University, and across the University of Maryland, College Park (UMCP) campus, forming sub-teams that included a large percentage of the initial initiative team. These collaborative research activities have emerged as a natural continuation of the convergent activities outlined in the first year, resulting in extensive breakthroughs towards the development of proof-of-concept explorative microsystems to address healthcare challenges. The details of the research outcomes are summarized in both multiple and single PI proposal submissions: including the internal University of Maryland AIM-HI challenge award on tackling chronic pain; the multidisciplinary 18-PI iPHASE DARPA proposal on ingestible pill hosting agents; the NSF-NCS proposal aimed at engineering solutions to investigate microbiome-to-neuron communication; the single-PI (Reza Ghodssi) NSF grant for closed-loop sensing and actuation of gastrointestinal capsule systems; and finally, a proposed NIH NIBIB grant to be submitted in October, 2020.

 

In addition, several recent publications featured in the Journal of Microelectromechanical Systems, Lab on a Chip, ACS Sensors, and Microsystems and Nanoengineering explore research subjects outlined by the NSF ERC stakeholder engagement workshop. One publication from the Ghodssi group, (L. A. Beardslee et al., ACS Sensors, 2020), presents an extensive review paper outlining recent advancements in ingestible sensors and devices, building a base of knowledge for which novel microsystem devices can be developed. Additionally, the NSF ERC grant has helped the groups achieve multiple awards such as, Ashley Chapin receiving the 2019-2020 Fischell Fellowship and winning the university-wide UMCP Three-Minute Thesis Competition, as well as Dr. Reza Ghodssi being selected for the Senior Faculty Outstanding Research Award from the A. James Clark School of Engineering. The collaborative research activities, in fulfillment of the NSF ERC planning grant mission have further engaged stakeholder participation and provided opportunities for researchers to continue development of transformative microsystems for GI monitoring. Finally, the entire effort has helped to firmly establish a foundation for the new Institute on the College Park Campus, the Robert E. Fischell Institute for Biomedical Devices. That is, the device-based ecosystem in Maryland has grown substantially, interactions such as those that stem from our grant have definitely contributed to its successes.

 

In sum, the ERC grant was instrumental in helping members move forward as a team with multiple different successful outcomes. The utilization of this grant allowed the team to do amazing work together to formulate the concept of microsystems devices to eventually formulate and submit a comprehensive, far-reaching ERC preproposal in January of 2019. Though this preproposal did not make it to the next level, the work has and will continue under this grant to improve and strengthen team building and collaborative efforts, with the majority of team members progressing to work together toward a future NSF ERC proposal in October of 2020.
